subject: Home & DIY
title: Wi-Fi's Smart Home Problem
description: A quick win: understand Wi-Fi's Smart Home Problem.

hook.text: Wi-Fi is everywhere but terrible for smart homes. Each device eats bandwidth, drains batteries, and jams the network.

buildup.text: Wi-Fi was built for streaming and browsing. Smart sensors send tiny packetsâ€”Wi-Fi is massive overkill for them.

discovery.text: A Wi-Fi chip draws 100-300 milliwatts. A Zigbee chip draws 1-2. That's why Wi-Fi sensors need mains power or charging.

twist.text: Most routers handle 20-30 devices. Add 50+ smart gadgets and the connection table fills up, causing random dropouts.

climax.text: Zigbee, Z-Wave, and Thread were built for smart homes: low power, low bandwidth, and self-healing mesh networking.

punchline.text: Wi-Fi is great for Netflix, terrible for light switches.

quiz.question: Why is Wi-Fi poorly suited for battery-powered smart sensors?
options: Wi-Fi chips draw 100-300x more power than Zigbee chips
Wi-Fi signals can't penetrate walls well enough
Wi-Fi requires a direct connection to each device
